"A pot of paint has been flung in the face of the public". Critics were horrified by its flatness, bright colors, eclectic style and mixed technique.
Style: Pure, flat, bright pure colors aggressively applied with vigorous brush strokes and thick paint, straight from the paint tubes to create a sense of an explosion. Unnatural color selection. Brown is purple, green is pink. Wild brush work and strident colors, subject simplification and abstraction. Primitive and less naturalistic. African and Oceanic art influences. Expressive potency of pure color. Eclectic style, mixed techniques. Colors of golden yellows, purples, incandescent blues. Rejection of traditional three-dimensional space and instead using flat areas or patches of color to create a new pictorial space.
Typical Subjects: Portrait, Still Life, Landscapes
Geographic Focus: Paris, France.
Interesting Facts: Critic Louis Vauxcelles disparaged the painters as "fauves" (wild beasts) thus becoming the movement's name.
Prominant Formats: Oil Painting, Canvas.
New or Dominant Materials: Oil paints.

Name: Northern Renaissance
A Quick Take: Darker tones and palette. Stiff poses. Precise, detailed, realistic and sometimes a grotesqueness of people. More landscapes. Lots of complex symbolism.
What You're To Feel: Somberness, moral, simplistic piety, spiritual, virtuous, humble.
Why You Should You Care: Dominant in major areas of Europe such as Germany, Switzerland, Austria, and the Low Countries (e.g. Netherlands). It provided major exposure of the principles of a more humble, toned down protestant viewpoint. Artists advanced the use of painting with oils (pigment and lindseed oil) thus influencing all of Renaissance artists.
Why it Evolved: 1430, was influenced by developing Early Italian Renaissance techniques. They began using linear perspective, realistic figures and other new techniques. The chaos and upheaval of the catholic church meant that there was no single artistic nucleus. Italian trade and printing. Expansion of religious subject matter to more real, human subjects. Discovey of classic liturature, sculpture. Translation of the Bible to German and French.
Why it Ended: Decline in Northern Europe followed Italy, just a little later. In Italy Mannerism became more popular. The Renaissance had achieved all artistic ideals, solved all problems. Young artists needed to find new expressions. Mannerism emerged.
Unique ????: Detailed brush strokes and painting style. Precise observation and naturalism, realistic and sometimes a grotesqueness of people. A detailed realism with use of Gothic elements and influence. No "decadent" Greek and Roman influences of Italian Renaissance and aversion to overblown religious themes but simplie devotional piety.
Relevant History: The new invention of printmaking (1436) in Northern Europe provided mass production and exposure to Protestant themes in Northern Reniassance art. Art and artists gained exposure with books, prints, engravings, and pamphlets building a new economy and fame of for artists themselves as well as their subjects.
Opinions and Commentary: "...The Germans, on the contrary (to Italians), had only one model: nature. Also if their poses have some stiffness, so their heads are almost all portraits, they have great charm and delicious naiveté in expression. In a way, they are closer to the truth." - Albert Durer.
Style: Darker tones and palette. More detailed reproduction of objects and their complex symbolic meaning than with the study of scientific perspective and anatomy even after these achievements became widely known. Artist used oil paints which allowed glazing (many thin transparent layers) and impasto (noticably thick layers strokes of paint).
Typical Subjects: Somber moods and darker psychological undertones and complicated symbolism. Common domestic scenes, moralistic themes. Landscape, portrait, animal, still life, biblical narrative, and rural labor and everyday life paintings. Specifically: Portraiture, landscape, genre, alleogry, philosophical, humor, satire, domestic scenes, merchants at work,  peasants in the fields and play, fantastical landscapes, dogs, cats, birds, children, household goods, nature, anatomy, perspective, architecture, accessories, actual life of the present, secular society. Devotional piety, spirituality, and living a simple life. A religous education, ritual and cultic practices, portrayal in tangible form the principles of Christianity, to conclusively identify biblical, religious scenes, convey religious meaning.
Geographic Focus: Northern Europe; North of Alps, Switzerland; Nuremberg, Germany; Austria; France; Britain; Low Countries, Flanders, Bruges; Poland
Interesting Facts: In addition the first to perfect oil painting the Dutch artists were some of the first western artists to specialize in landscapes. "Renaissance" is a French word that means "rebirth".
Prominant Formats: Painting, portraiture, prints, wood sculptures, engraving, altar painting.
New or Dominant Materials: Oil painting using pigments and linseed oil (and nut oil) was introduced to Europe by Northern Renaissance artists (earlest is is 7th century AD). Printing technology (1436) created: books, prints, engravings, and pamphlets. Woods for sculpture.

Name: Realism / Naturalism
A Quick Take: Realistic subject of art not the method. Stark, truthful, unidealized, realistic painting of everyday common scenes and laborers and nature. Rejected the overly emotional, romantic, unreal and unnatural.
What You're To Feel: Rebellion, sympathy to ordinary people and workers, social awareness, political awareness, toil, life's difficulties, challenges.
Why You Should You Care: It is regarded as the beginning of the modern art movement pushing to incorporate modern life and art together. Photography became important medium. Realism spread all over Europe and to as far as Russia.
Why it Evolved: Artists rejected the exotic subjects, drama, and exaggerated emotionalism of the dominant Romantic movement. The realism of photography emerged. A series of French rebellions involving laborers promoted a spirit of rebellion. The Historical Painting (large, grand, state-sponsored artworks) movement was an "establisment" art movement, thus rejected as well.
Why it Ended: Still popular now it has become diluted, fragmented and morphed into new movements. In some places reclassified as anything not "abstract" or "surreal".
Unique ????: The real-life "content depicted" rather than the "realistic method" of painting.
Relevant History: Influenced by The 1848 Revolution. It was part of a wave of revolutions in 1848 in Europe that involved incidences of bloody but unsuccessful rebellion by the Paris workers.
Opinions and Commentary: "Labor was a major issue in the second half of the century due to decades of industrialization.." - Art History Teaching Resources.
Style: Generally the attempt to represent subject matter truthfully, without artificiality and avoiding artistic conventions. Accurate depiction of lifeforms, perspective, and the details of light and color. Scenes and objects are depicted with great skill and care. Avoids artistic conventions, or implausible, exotic, and supernatural elements (but did paint angels). Naturalism, a sub-movement of Realism, avoided politics and social issues focusing soley on nature. "How" a subject is painted, rather than "who" or "what" it is.
Typical Subjects: Social realism and labor. Rural lifestyle, daily lifestyle of everyday people and laborers, social realism, contemporary life, still lifes, flowers, landscapes. Naturalism, as a sub-movement, avoided politics and social issues.
Geographic Focus: England, France, Germany, Northern Europe, Russia.
Interesting Facts: Little to no realism sculpture or architecture.  Famous painter / activist Gustov Courbet was involved in pullng down memorial column with Napoleon atop in the Place Vendôme. Unable to pay restitutions, Courbet went into self-imposed exile in Switzerland.
Prominant Formats: Photography, Oil Painting, Canvas.
New or Dominant Materials: Photography, perfect for realistic depiction of life. Oil painting.

Name: Romanticism
A Quick Take: Not literally "romantic" subjects. Moody. Exaggerated dipictions of nature, ethereal and foggy backgrounds. Unrestrained visible brushstrokes, lots of color.
What You're To Feel: Intense emotions. Individualistic, exotic, beautiful, apprehension, horror, terror, and awe. Passion, sensitivity, and imaginative. The glory of the past. The importance, awe-inspiring, healing aspect and beauty of nature. Medieval in the attempt to escape population growth, early urban sprawl, and industrialism. Distrustful of the human world.  A restless spirit, striding beyond old and cramping forms. Longing for the unbounded and the indefinable, for perpetual movement and change. Heroic individualism, self-assertion both individual and collective. Patriotism, nationalism. Struggling for independnce.
Why You Should You Care: A worldwide influential art movement and a philosophy you will see in literature, music, art, architecture, theology and much more.
Why it Evolved: Challenged the approach of Enlightenment. Emotions, not logic and reason. Sought a stronger connection to nature.
Why it Ended: The English Romantic Period officially ended with the coronation of Queen Victoria in 1837. The Industrial Revolution began as the working class became dominant in the culture.
Unique ????: Moody, themes of nature and heroic individualism.
Relevant History: Nationalism and independence movements were sweeping the world. The ideologies of the French Revolution influenced many early Romantics who were cultural revolutionaries and sympathetic to the revolution. The 1815 Napoleonic Wars had societal impact. The theory of evolution was growing in popularity.
Opinions and Commentary: "the artist's feeling is his law" - David Friedrich. “Romanticism is precisely situated neither in choice of subject nor in exact truth, but in a way of feeling,” - Charles Baudelaire.
Style: Unrefined outlines, unrestrained brushstrokes, and the emphasis on color over form makes the painterly style the choice of the Romantics. Visible brushstrokes, which lend themselves to an energy and immediacy to the painting. Ethereal and foggy Backgrounds. 3D drawing and representation.
Typical Subjects: Not literally "romance" subjects. Landscapes, wild landscapes, storms and the overwhelming awe-inspiring impact of and connection to, nature. Glory of the past. Patriotism, nationalism, struggle for independence. Medieval rather than the classical.
Geographic Focus: Paris, France. England. Worldwide.
Interesting Facts: "Romantic chess" emphasized quick, tactical maneuvers characterized by aesthetic beauty rather than long-term strategic planning.
Prominant Formats: Painting on canvas, scultpture.
New or Dominant Materials: Oil painting.

Name: Surrealism
A Quick Take: Startling, mad, weird, using strange images. More a philosophy and unconscious thoughts than an art form.
What You're To Feel: Surprised, startled, philosophical, dream-like, unnerved, illogical, disoriented, an enhanced emotional intimacy, empathy.
Why You Should You Care: Extremely influential form of art and widespread with a remarkably different style of radical looking art with many recognized artist names (Dalí, Magritte). It is often used to symbolize what is modern art.
Why it Evolved: Artists wanted to represent philosophy not subject matter. Freud's work with free association, dream analysis, and the unconscious was an influence. The group aimed to revolutionize human experience, in its personal, cultural, social, and political aspects. They reflected freedom from false rationality, and restrictive customs and structures.
Why it Ended: It remains popular but also fragmented and diluted by the many derivative movements that it influenced.
Unique ????: More an expression of philosophy and not the actual art-making itself. It attempts to expose psychological truth; stripping ordinary objects of their normal significance, to create a compelling image that was beyond ordinary formal organization in order to evoke empathy from the viewer.
Relevant History: It began in the climate of the dissolutionment due to the aftermath of WW I. World War II created an environment of havoc especially for the European artists and writers that opposed Fascism and Nazism. During the 1930s Peggy Guggenheim, an important American art collector and market-maker, promoted Surrealists.
Opinions and Commentary: "resolve the previously contradictory conditions of dream and reality into an absolute reality, a super-reality". - André Breton. "There is only one difference between a madman and me. I am not mad." - Salvador Dalí.
Style: Automatism, automatic, free-association drawing as a method of art-making, suppressing conscious control over the creation process. Allowing the unconscious mind to direct creation. A use of surprise, unexpected juxtapositions imaging, non sequiturs and dreamlike representations. Spontaneity without censoring thoughts. Ordinary and depictive expressions with a large range of imagination
Typical Subjects: Reflection of the human experience, in its personal, cultural, social, and political aspects. An unlocking of the subconscious. Enhanced sense of emotional intimacy. Subjects unnerving, illogical, strange as an unconscious expression, dream and unreality. Paradoxical, absurd, Illogical. cerebral. Incoherenent and distorted. Occasional reference to communism and anarchism.
Geographic Focus: Paris, France; London, Birmingham, England; New York, United States.
Interesting Facts: During the 1930s Peggy Guggenheim, an important American art collector, from a famous family, married Max Ernst and began promoting work by other Surrealists such as Yves Tanguy and the British artist John Tunnard.
Prominant Formats: Oil painting on canvas. Large variety of visual art formats. Theater. Writing.
New or Dominant Materials: Frottage (rubbing pastel or pencil on paper over uneven surface), Grattage ("scratching" fresh paint with a sharp blade), Decalcomania (engravings and prints transferred to pottery or other materials). Mixed Media (mixed use of different materials). Oil painting using pigments and linseed oil (and nut oil).

Name: Symbolism
A Quick Take: Like viewing a dream or vision.
What You're To Feel: Dreaming, sexuality, erotic, the mystic, sadness, melancholy, the unreal.
Why You Should You Care: A visually distrinctive form of art by well known artists representing a major influential, worldwide movement in writing and poetry.
Why it Evolved: A rejection of realism and reflection of popular French liturature of the time. Artistic desire to visualize truths symbolically and through metaphorical images. Reaction against Naturalism and Realism movements.
Why it Ended: It evolved to Influence future styles such as Art Nouveau, Les Nabis, Expressionism and Surrealism. Bridged previous movements into the Modern art.
Unique ????: Painted a psychological, spiritual reality rendering dreams and visions. It used metaphors not literal symbols.
Relevant History: Symbolism was more a poetic, literary movement than an art movement.
Opinions and Commentary: “is to clothe the idea in sensuous form” - Albert Aurier.
Style: Not a style in technique but more a poetic philosophy.
Typical Subjects: Mythological and dream imagery. Personal visions. Intensely personal, erotic, private, obscure, melancholy, evil and ambiguous references. Mystic and sometimes occult, perverse, morbid subject matter. Did not rely on literal emblems and symbols.
Geographic Focus: Paris, France; Russia; Belgium.
Interesting Facts: The American Edgar Allan Poe was a significant influence on French liturature at the time.
Prominant Formats: Oil Painting on Canvas.
New or Dominant Materials: Oil painting using pigments and lindseed oil.
